data.title: From Darius Garland to Alex Poythress, The Tennessean's 2010s All-Decade boys basketball team
data.meta_description: The Nashville area produced major college caliber talent throughout the 2010-19 decade. Here is The Tennessean's All-Decade 2010s boys basketball team.
data.text:
The Nashville area produced several boys high school basketball players who became major college prospects and some who went on to play in the NBA during the 2010-19 decade.

Some of the most prolific scorers in Tennessee high school basketball history played in that decade including Brentwood Academy's Darius Garland, Maplewood's Bo Hodges, Fayetteville's Nick Hopkins, Marshall County's Kedren Johnson and KJ Johnson, Clay County's Tyreke Key and Northeast's Alex Poythress. Each scored more than 2,000 career points and averaged more than 25 points per game.

Here are the top high school boys basketball players from 2010-19. The athlete's year they graduated are in parenthesis.

Jordan Bone

Ensworth | Guard (2016)

Two-time All-State ... Mr. Basketball finalist ... a 6-foot-2 ball-handler who helped lead Ensworth to two state championships (2013 and 2014) along with one runner-up finish as a senior in 2015 and a 24-6 record ... averaged 20.1 points, 5.5 assists, 4.0 rebounds and 2.1 steals as a senior ... Ensworth posted an 83-37 record in Bone's four seasons on the roster ... rated as the state's No. 6 prospect and the nation's 222nd overall player by 247Sports ... older brother Josh played at Brentwood Academy and UT and is now an assistant at Tennessee State ... signed with Tennessee ... set the Vols single-season record for assist/turnover ratio at 2.91 as a junior and owns the career record at 2.70 ... averaged 13.5 points and 5.8 assists as a junior ... All-SEC second team ... declared for the NBA Draft after his junior season ... selected in the second round of the NBA Draft by the New Orleans Pelicans then traded to Detroit.

Craig Bradshaw

Christ Presbyterian Academy | Guard (2012)

All-State ... Mr. Basketball ... Tennessean All-Midstate ... an extremely athletic and versatile 6-2 sharpshooter who led CPA to a 37-2 record and the Class 2A state championship as a senior ... state tournament MVP ... had more than 2,000 career points, 900 assists and 600 rebounds ... averaged 18.6 points, 5.9 rebounds, and 3.9 assists as senior ... shot 55.7% from the field ... Region 5-AA most valuable player ... four-time all-district and three-time all-region ... Led CPA in scoring as junior with an 18.7 point average ... was also an all-district golfer ... signed with Belmont ... became the Bruins' sixth all-time NCAA Division I scoring leader with 1,698 points ... three-year starter who led Belmont to two NCAA Tournament berths (2013 and 2015) ... two-time All-Ohio Valley Conference first team and one time second team ... All-OVC 75th Anniversary Team ... played professionally in Germany ... returned to CPA as an assistant coach in 2021.

Corn Elder

Ensworth | Guard (2013)

All-State ... a 5-10 playmaker who was The Tennessean Player of the Year ... two-time All-Midstate ... averaged 20.2 points, 4.7 assists, 4.5 rebound and 4.2 steals as a senior ... three-time state tournament MVP ... also played football, was Mr. Football in 2011 and made The Tennessean All-Decade football team (2010-19) as a defensive back ... said he preferred playing basketball in college but signed with Miami (Fla.) to play football ... also received scholarship offers to play football from Tennessee, Vanderbilt, Mississippi State, Ole Miss, Georgia Tech, North Carolina and Cincinnati ... had offers to play basketball from MTSU and Jacksonville ... started in 21 football games at Miami and recorded 158 career tackles ... selected in the fifth round of the 2017 NFL Draft by the Carolina Panthers ... played three seasons with Carolina and one with Washington.

More: Meet The Tennessean's All-Decade 2000s high school boys basketball team

More: From Ron Mercer to Ron Slay, meet The Tennessean's 1990s all-decade boys basketball team

More: Nashville's top boys high school basketball players in the 1980s from Carlus Groves to Barry Booker

Darius Garland

Brentwood Academy | Guard (2018)

McDonald's All-American ... three-time Mr. Basketball ... three-time Tennessean Player of the Year ... Gatorade Tennessee Player of the Year ... Jordan Brand Classic All-American ... a dynamic 6-2 guard who led Brentwood Academy to a record-tying four state championships ... scored more than 2,500 career points ... averaged 27.6 points, 5.0 rebounds and 4.3 assists as a senior ... shot 59.7% from the field ... four-year starter ... consensus 5-star prospect ... father Winston played seven seasons in the NBA ... signed with Vanderbilt after narrowing choices to Duke, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky and UCLA ... played in only five games at Vanderbilt due to a knee injury ... declared eligible for the NBA Draft after his freshman season ... selected in the first round (fifth overall pick) in the draft by the Cleveland Cavaliers ... 2022 NBA All-Star reserve ... career average 18.4 points, 6.7 assists and 2.4 rebounds.

Bo Hodges

Maplewood | Forward (2017)

Two-time All-State ... two-time Mr. Basketball ... Tennessean Male Athlete of the Year ... two-time Tennessean All-Midstate ... a 6-3 swing player who led Maplewood to its first basketball state championship, which snapped Metro Nashville's 21-year boys basketball drought without a title ... state tournament MVP ... had more than 2,000 career points, 1,800 rebounds, 700 assists, 500 steals and 300 blocked shots ... averaged 25.8 points and 12.0 rebounds per game as a senior ... also played football and ran track ... signed with East Tennessee State ... Southern Conference Freshman of the Year and All-Southern Conference third team as a sophomore ... transferred to Butler for his final two years of eligibility and was the Bulldogs' leading rebounder (6.9) and second-leading scorer (10.0) as a senior.

Nick Hopkins

Fayetteville | Guard (2016)

USA Today Tennessee first team ... Mr. Basketball ... a prolific 6-0 shooter who became Fayetteville's all-time leading scorer with 2,851 career points ... state's leading scorer as a senior with a 33.3 point average ... scored nearly 1,000 points as a senior ... had 40 or more points in seven games, including a career-high 54 against Huntland and 51 against Marshall County ... averaged 22.0 points as a junior and 19.2 points as a sophomore ... averaged 6.4 rebounds, 3.3 steals and 3.1 assists as a senior ... four-time all-district ... selected to play in the Tennessee Basketball Coaches Association All-Star game ... signed with Belmont ... set the Bruins' single-game debut scoring record with 22 points against Washington as a freshman ... became a part-time starter as a sophomore ... transferred to Siena for his final two seasons and was the team captain as a senior.

More: From David Vaughn to Charles Davis, meet The Tennessean's 1970s All-Decade boys basketball team

More: From Perry Wallace to Ted McClain, The Tennessean's 1960s All-Decade boys basketball team

Kedren Johnson

Marshall County | Guard (2011)

All-State ... Mr. Basketball ... two-time Tennessean Player of the Year ... a talented 6-4 guard who became Marshall County's all-time leading scorer with 2,442 career points ... averaged 27.3 points, 10.0 rebounds and 8.0 assists as a senior ... also became Marshall County's all-time assists leader ... set the school record for single-game scoring with 55 points in an 81-54 win over East Hickman ... led Marshall County to the state semifinals as a senior ... four-time district MVP ... signed with Vanderbilt where he became a starter as a sophomore and averaged 13.5 points and 3.5 rebounds ... scored a career-high 28 points against Davidson ... transferred to Memphis after his sophomore season.

Keon Johnson

Webb School | Guard (2019)

All-State ... two-time Mr. Basketball ... Tennessean Player of the Year ... two-time All-Midstate ... an explosive 6-5 shooting guard who averaged 24.6 points, 8.6 rebounds and 3.2 assists as a junior ... led Webb to the state semifinals and a 29-7 record ... missed the majority of his senior year after suffering a knee injury ... rated as a top-30 prospect nationally by Rivals, 247Sports and ESPN ... mother Conswella Sparrow was a two-time All-SEC basketball player at Auburn ... signed with Tennessee ... SEC All-Freshman Team ... led Vols in field goals made (111) and attempted (247) ... declared eligible for the NBA Draft after his freshman season and was selected in the first round by the New York Knicks (21st overall) and traded to the L.A. Clippers on draft night ... traded to Portland in his rookie season ... spent this past season with the Brooklyn Nets.

KJ Johnson

Marshall County | Guard (2019)

Four-time All-State ... Two-time Mr. Basketball ... two-time Tennessean All-Midstate ... an outstanding 6-2 scorer who became Marshall County's all-time leading scorer with more than 2,500 career points ... scored 1,000 points in his junior and senior seasons ... averaged 34.8 points as a senior and 34.1 as a junior ... scored a school-record 57 points in the season opener as a senior ... scored at least 50 points in three games and 40 in nine games ... had a triple-double against Nolensville (29 points, 10 rebounds, 10 assists) ... made 114 3-pointers as a junior (3.6 per game average) ... signed with Lipscomb ... Atlantic Sun All-Freshman Team ... one of just three Bisons to play in every game that season with 16 starts ... second on the team in scoring as a sophomore (13.5 ppg.) ... transferred to North Alabama where he started his last two seasons ... finished his career with 1,649 points between Lipscomb and North Alabama.

Braxton (Blackwell) Key

Christ Presbyterian Academy | Forward (2016)

All-State ... two-time Mr. Basketball ... a 6-8 four-star prospect and the No. 38-ranked player nationally by 247Sports who led CPA to the state championship and two semifinal appearances ... CPA was 103-10 in his three seasons .... averaged 20.7 points, 10.5 rebounds and 4.9 assists as a junior ... transferred to Oak Hill Academy for his senior season and led Oak Hill to the national championship and a 45-1 record ... signed with Alabama after also considering Tennessee, Vanderbilt, Kansas, Florida, Indiana, Louisville, Texas and Ohio State ... SEC All-Freshman Team ... transferred to Virginia after his sophomore season ... part-time starter as a junior and fulltime as a senior ... averaged 9.9 points and 7.4 rebounds as a senior ... just finished his fifth NBA season with Denver after playing the previous two in Detroit.

Tyreke Key

Clay County | Guard (2017)

All-State ... Mr. Basketball as a senior and finalist as a junior ... Tennessean All-Midstate ... at 6-3 point and shooting guard who scored 3,237 career points, which was 11th most in Tennessee basketball history ... as a senior led the state with a 37.4 point per game average, which set the state record for points in a season (1,383) breaking a 25-year-old record held previously by Tony Delk (1,312) ... led Clay County to the state tournament semifinals ... state tournament MVP ... set state tournament record for most points in a game with 54 against Loretto and in the state tournament (128) ... led Clay County to a 63-8 record over his junior and senior seasons ... averaged 28.1 points as a junior ... signed with Indiana State ... Missouri Valley Conference All-Freshman Team ... led the MVC in scoring as a sophomore (17.8) and was third as a junior (15.6) ... transferred to Tennessee for his final year of eligibility in 2022-23 and helped the Vols advance to the Sweet 16 ... started in 15 games and was the team's second-best 3-point shooter (33.3%).

Jalen Lindsey

Christ Presbyterian Academy | Forward (2014)

All-State ... Mr. Basketball ... two-time Tennessean All-Midstate ... a 6-7 post player who led CPA to the state championship in 2012 and 2013 ... two-time state tournament MVP ... averaged 19.3 points and 7.9 rebounds as a junior ... transferred to Huntingdon Prep in West Virginia for his senior season ... Ranked as the nation's No. 69 top college prospect by Rivals.com, 84th by Scout.com and ESPN, and 100th by CBS 247 ... signed with Providence ... started in 91 games and scored 993 career points.

Grayson Murphy

Independence | Guard (2017)

All-State ... two-time Tennessean All-Midstate ... a 6-1 point guard who became Independence's all-time leader in points (2,093), rebounds (717), assists (591) and steals (393) ... led Independence to the state tournament semifinals ... averaged 19.7 points, 5.2 assists and 3.1 steals as a senior ... had 43 points, 12 assists, nine rebounds and nine assists in a game against McGavock as a junior ... averaged 18.6 points and 5.6 rebounds as a junior ... signed with Belmont ... became a starter as a sophomore and was second in the OVC and 14th nationally in assists per game (6.5) ... two-time All-OVC, two-time All-OVC Defensive Player of the Year ... two-time Lou Henson Mid-Major All-American ... OVC all-time leader in assists (775) and steals (281) ... only player in college basketball over the last 30 seasons to have more than 1,000 career points, 800 rebounds, 700 assists and 250 steals ... began his professional career in Germany ... signed to the Los Angeles Lakers Summer League roster on July 2.

Ruot Monyyong

Whites Creek | Center (2017)

Two-time Tennessean All-Midstate ... a dominant 6-9 post player who led the Cobras to back-to-back state tournament appearances, the first coming in 2016 which was the school's first since 2007 ... led Whites Creek to the state tournament semifinals and a 29-6 record as a junior .... had 25 points and 18 rebounds in state tournament quarterfinal win over Sheffield ... averaged 18.8 points, 16.1 rebounds and 8.5 blocks per game as a senior ... averaged 18.4 points, 14.1 rebounds and 6.1 blocks as a junior ... played at Hunters Lane as a freshman before transferring to Whites Creek ... ESPN 3-star prospect ... spent first two years out of high school at two different junior colleges before signing with Arkansas-Little Rock ... All-Sun Belt Conference, Sun Belt Conference Defensive Player of the Year and Newcomer of the Year as a junior ... Preseason Sun Belt Player of the Year as a senior ... averaged 11.9 points and 10.9 rebounds as a senior.

Alex Poythress

Northeast | Forward (2012)

Parade All-American ... McDonald's All-American ... Mr. Basketball ... Tennessee Gatorade Player of the Year ... All-State ... Tennessean Player of the Year ... the 6-8 Poythress averaged 31.1 points, 11.5 rebounds, 4.3 blocks, 2.1 assists and 1.3 steals as a senior while leading the Eagles to a 28-3 record and the Region 5-AAA quarterfinals ... shot 67.0% from the field, 77.1% from the free throw line and 37.3% from the 3-point line ... scored 2,080 career points ... ranked as the nation's No. 7 overall player and No. 3 small forward by Scout.com and 13th overall and No. 3 at his position by ESPN ... signed with Kentucky and started in 31 of 33 games as a freshman ... SEC All-Freshman Team ... finished his career playing in 112 games with 62 starts ... had 966 career points, 597 rebounds and 77 blocks becoming just the 12th player in Kentucky history with at least 900 points, 500 rebounds and 70 blocks ... after going undrafted in the 2016 NBA Draft joined the Orlando Magic in the Summer League ... spent three seasons in the NBA with Philadelphia, Indiana and Atlanta.

Coach

Hubie Smith

Brentwood Academy | 2014-19

Hubie Smith won seven state championships during his four decades as a high school basketball coach including four consecutively (2015-18) as the Brentwood Academy boys coach. Smith retired in 2019 after his last team finished runner-up in the state. Smith's last five Brentwood Academy teams posted a 137-19 record. Smith won more than 700 games in his career. He became only the third coach in Tennessee to win four straight high school titles. In 2017 Smith was named Tennessee high school basketball coach of the year by USA Today and in 2018 was the boys basketball coach of the year by The Tennessean. Smith developed several outstanding players during the 2010-09 decade including Darius Garland, Jeremiah Oatsvall, Cam Johnson and Marcus Fitzgerald. Earlier in his career Smith spent 19 years as the boys coach at Bartlett where he won the 2001 state title and as the Ensworth girls coach where he won the 2010 and 2013 state titles. Smith also served as an assistant coach at Belmont and Lipscomb. He was inducted into the TSSAA Hall of Fame in 2019.

Reach Mike Organ at 615-295-8021 or on X @MikeOrganWriter.
